page.title: 07THE LIGHTHOUSE,WITHERNSEA
page.content: Withernsea's most dominant feature is its white-washed lighthouse,situated not on the sea but at a road junction about 300 yards inland.It is 135 ft tall and stands in a 300 ft long plot with a 3 bed-roomed house attached to it.It was built in 1893 and was sited inland largely to take account of the erosion of the coast.It was closed down in 1976 due to the advance of modern technology which enables the lighthouses to north and south at Flamborough and Spurn Point to cover the whole of the Holderness coast. When operative the light shone 17 miles out to sea and there would be 3 flashes every minute.The bulb structure floated on a bed of mercury and it could be pushed with one finger.The lighthouse has 147 steps to the top and although still owned by Trinity House it is now up for sale.
